thread.title: Business Breakfast LIVE: Small firms raise concerns over having to check EU workers after Brexit

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Business Breakfast LIVE: Small firms raise concerns over having to check EU workers after Brexit
text:
The FTSE-100 index at 7:44am was unchanged at 7128.10.
The pound at 8am was 1.2883 dollars compared to 1.2755 dollars at the previous close.
The euro at 8am was 0.8822 pounds compared to 0.8872 pounds at the previous close. 8:10 KEY EVENT Concerns raised by small firms over checks for EU workers
Small firms have voiced a “deep concern” over the prospect of having to check the eligibility of EU workers in the case of a no-deal Brexit.
Immigration Minister Caroline Nokes said earlier this week that employers will be tasked with checking whether EU nationals have the right to work in the UK after if the UK fails to strike a Brexit deal.
But the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) said smaller companies would struggle to cope with the “additional burden”.
FSB chairman Mike Cherry said:
Small businesses are not the Home Office and should not be expected to undertake their job.
The reality is that many of these businesses wouldn’t have the first idea of where, or how, to check whether or not their EU staff have the right to work here.
Most small firms don’t have HR or legal departments to deal with complex immigration procedures, or the time and resources to deal with the additional administrative burden this would bring.
Mr Cherry added that the Government has yet to release any information about what businesses will be required to do if they hire staff from the EU, or already have EU workers on their payroll.
He said:
This is baffling with less than five months until the UK leaves the EU and is leaving small firms and their EU employees in the dark. Mike Cherry, chair of the Federation of Small Businesses (Image: Handout) More On
